thread.title: Parkland field hockey team shows improvement, holds off Nazareth
thread.title_full: Parkland field hockey team shows improvement, holds off Nazareth

title: Parkland field hockey team shows improvement, holds off Nazareth
text:
Complete Box Score » 
Sometimes the negatives can be used as a rallying point to turn into a positive. 
Parkland High School’s field hockey team was coming off Saturday’s disappointing 3-3 tie with Pocono Mountain East, which has won just three games this season. 
The Trojans turned in a performance that was more to first-year coach Lizzy Millen’s liking on Tuesday afternoon. 
Jenna Lysakowski , Grace Royer and Rachel Rizzetto scored first half goals and Parkland held off a late Nazareth rally to post a 3-2 Eastern Pennsylvania Conference Skyline Division victory over the visiting Blue Eagles. 
The game was delayed 30 minutes due to thunder and lightning and was played in a light rain throughout. 
RELATED : Parkland staff made right call to play Tuesday's game against Nazareth 
“I just thought at the end of the day it came down to us really executing,” Millen said, “because in this kind of weather the girls aren’t always going to make the best decisions. In these conditions I knew the game would be unexpecting.” 
Millen briefly flashed her thoughts back to the Pocono Mountain East game. 
“I didn’t think it was our worst game, but I thought we’d hit a little lull,” Millen said. “We addressed it, and the girls really picked up their game today.” 
“I think we played really well today,” said Royer, who leads Parkland (7-3-1 overall, 4-3-1 league) with 10 goals. “Our passing was really on even though we had to thing about it because it was slow and wet.” 
Royer can feel the camaraderie of the team picking up. 
“We have a good attitude,” she said. “We were real supportive of each other today.” 
Lysakowsk scored less than seven minutes into the game to start a three-goal barrage between the teams in the next two minutes. 
Emilly Wahlgren scored for Nazareth to tie it 1-1 before Royer answered right back to put the Trojans in front to stay, 2-1, with 21:47 left in the first half. 
“It really all stems from the forwards,” said Royer, who splits time between forward and midfield. “They all work hard to get it up there. The ball tipped off the defender and I shot it and it went in. It really gave us momentum.” 
Lauren Resh made it interesting when her goal pulled Nazareth (7-5, 6-5) within 3-2 with 13:12 left in the game. However, the Trojans held off Nazareth’s challenge with the help of goalkeeper Brie Barraco, who made eight saves. 
“We were expecting a pretty good game,” Royer said. “They tied us last year. They’re a strong team and we were expecting a pretty good fight.” 
Millen might have felt some tension on the sideline. But she thought it was a good game from the spectators’ point of view. 
“Both teams worked really hard,” she said. “It was a fun game to watch.” 
Tom Hinkel may be reached at thinkel@lehighvalleylive.com . Follow him on Twitter @TomHinkelLV . Find Lehigh Valley high school sports on Facebook
